body: MANY people with children in New York City know about the highly regarded Public School 87 on the Upper West Side, or Public School 6 on the Upper East Side. In those schools, many students test above the norm in reading and math, and their parents can be assured, in most cases, that they have access to a decent education. But in those
title: Finding a Neighborhood and a School

body: NEW YORK's hot heroes speak many languages. No, not the buff guys in the the firefighter calendar, but those long, crisp and slightly chewy rolls filled with meat or cheese and served hot from the oven or grill. They are working-class sandwiches, which provide comfort and sustenance any time of day or night. After writing about cold heroes last
title: Lo, a New Age of Heroes

body: THE Italian men's club at Court Street and Fourth Place in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, does not value uninvited guests, as the ''Members Only'' sign on the door makes perfectly clear. Through a window in the front door, a curious drop-in visitor can glimpse a big-screen television, a few lawn chairs stacked in the corner, and a painting of George
title: CITY LORE; A Glass Of Grappa? The Door's Open.

body: THE difference between Frankies 457 Court Street Spuntino and the trattorias multiplying across New York is that Frankies serves gravy. Granted, the menu calls it marinara, and some servers say sauce, but many of Frankies' customers -- the long-nailed women mopping their plates with bread, the tough teenager barking a request for more -- refer to
title: $25 AND UNDER; Real Italian-American, Gravy and All

body: These days, when customers walk into the House of Pizza and Calzone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, they have a standard greeting for Paul Diagostino, who bought the 52-year-old neighborhood institution in September with his future brother-in-law, Gino Vitale. ''You the new owner?'' they say, eyes narrowing in suspicion. Then, with a frown and an
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; With Patrons Wary, a New Pizza Man Strives to Fill Some Fabled Shoes

body: The shelves are stacked with vinegars and jellies, fizzy waters and pastes, peppercorns, juniper berries and 29 kinds of olive oil. Hooks coming down from the ceiling hang heavy with bags of onions, cuts of meat and sausages the size of sandbags. Behind the counter, Frank Caputo and his brother, Vito, are tending shop while the old man takes their
title: Get Your Cheese While It's Hot; Refrigeration Rules and Old Ways Clash, With Fresh Mozzarella at Risk

body: BUZZY O'KEEFE'S foie gras vendors thought he was nuts when he opened the tony River Cafe in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1977. ''Everybody in New York said I was out of my mind, that nobody would come to Brooklyn,'' he said. ''When I first opened up,'' he added, ''they were afraid.'' That was then. Now that once-grotty waterfront parcel is
title: LIVING IN/Brooklyn Heights; A Graceful Bastion in a Swirling Borough

body: THERE are very few ways to outwit the market and find a bargain. But for those people who are adventurous and willing to look at buildings that don't fall into their preconceived ideas of residential space, there is a frontier, maybe the last one: the mixed use building, legally designated as part commercial and part residential. Brokers say they
title: The Benefits Of Living Above The Store

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: It's no secret that you can get a great meal outside Manhattan, sometimes even saving a few dollars in the process. Here are some newer places -- both pricey and not -- that have opened in the last few years in Brooklyn and Queens. BUTCHER BROS. STEAK HOUSE (718) 267-2771; 29-33 Newtown Avenue, Astoria, Queens; $$$; Diner's Journal: 9/10/04.

body: UNLIKE people who search intently for the ideal home, Caroline and David Gould realized early on they were willing to settle for something good enough. ''We didn't want to be one of those couples who looked for the perfect apartment for a year,'' Ms. Gould said. ''A lot of people look at a trillion things. We looked at maybe 10. It was more about
title: THE HUNT; Climbing the Ladder, One Rung at a Time

body: IT is curiosity, above all, that puts this baby, at least provisionally, on the list of the fall's must-sees. What could a show so bluntly and broadly titled as ''Brooklyn, the Musical'' possibly deliver? A choral dirge in which sad legions take to the stage to lament the flight of the Dodgers, perhaps. A shaggy bunch of Williamsburg neo-bohemians
title: THE NEW SEASON/THEATER; A Girl Named Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: I thought ''Where Does She Live? The Suburbs, She Whispered'' was amusing, and I could relate to Leslie Kaufman's worries about losing street cred as a New Yorker living in the suburbs. But as a teacher and as someone who attended public schools here, I took offense at her characterization of New York City public schools. I realize
title: City or Suburbs? That Is the Question

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: WORKING from home went well for Michael Friedman as long as he worked alone. Then, as his one-man public relations business grew, he seriously considered hiring an employee. But he knew it would be awkward having someone come to work in his apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn -- a railroad flat where his small office opened right into the
title: THE HUNT; Outgrowing The Home Office

title: Their Political Odyssey

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Cintra Wilson; Funny Girl

body: THEY could be called the New York Muses Against Bush-Cheney. They are about 30 poets, who will be reading their poetry during the Republican National Convention week in New York, as a protest against four more years of the Bush administration. But despite their concern with hot-button issues -- the war in Iraq, tax cuts -- they are hoping that in a
title: COPING; Protesting In Verse, Not Shouts

body: The drive-in theaters that once dotted the suburban landscape are all but extinct, yet for New Yorkers the pleasures of open-air screenings live on. In addition to the Monday-night movies in Bryant Park, sponsored by HBO, the Brooklyn-based Rooftop Films has been offering short films at the Old American Can Factory in Brooklyn, Pier 26 in Manhattan
title: Tar Cinema: Watching Shorts On the Roof

body: A 63-year-old woman was in critical condition yesterday after she was struck while crossing a street in Carroll Gardens, the police said. The woman, who was not identified, suffered multiple fractures and was taken to Lutheran Medical Center, the police said. She was struck about 10 a.m. at Fourth Avenue and First Street by a 1993 Ford Escort. The
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Struck Crossing Street

body: This weekend, the rising temperatures drove many New York City dwellers to the shore, the mountains or the air-conditioning. She was asked if she had a pool. ''Do I got
title: Pools Above Ground Help Keep a City Cool

title: About New York; As Jingle Plays, Resistance Is Futile

body: Peter Scotti's earliest memories of Brooklyn are all about figs. ''Every house on the block had a fig tree in the back, and a statue of the Virgin Mary or a saint in front,'' he said. For decades, Mr. Scotti, 65, has kept alive his family's tradition of tending to fig trees, which have been in neighborhoods like Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, since
title: Carroll Gardens Journal; A Tree Dies in Brooklyn (Alas, It's a Fig)

body: To the Editor: ''The Mystery of the Trembling Apartment,'' by Paul von Zielbauer (Urban Studies, May 30), reminded me of my own experience some years ago. In 1965, when I was first married, my wife and I moved in to an apartment on Hicks Street near State Street in Brooklyn. Like Mr. von Zielbauer's apartment house in Carroll Gardens, at least as
title: When Brooklyn Gets the Shakes

body: David Barriera arrived at St. Jude's Roman Catholic School in Canarsie, Brooklyn, with what should have been an easy job. He was there for a community meeting, to explain that his employer, the City Department of Youth and Community Development, wants to give Canarsie up to $100,000 a year in federal money for local social programs. But Mr.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CANARSIE; For Some in a Proud Neighborhood, a Free Gift Bears Too High a Price

body: Take a whisper of a breath, Mr. and Ms. New York. Think about palm trees and trade winds, and tell us how you feel about loud noise and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's sweeping new plan to reduce the cacophony in the big, brawling, brash city. ''He can't turn Brooklyn into Pleasantville,'' said Melanie Camporeale, 21, who dishes out Italian ices at
title: Trying to Tame the Noise In the City Is No Easy Sell

body: A WHILE back, I awoke in my Carroll Gardens apartment to find it shaking. Whatever, man. It had been one very long work week, and I went back to sleep. When I finally got up, things were calm. I forgot about the shaking. Then, weeks later, it happened again. And again. Having experienced a few L.A. earthquakes, I took closer measure of this most
title: URBAN STUDIES/SHAKING; The Mystery of the Trembling Apartment

body: JOE'S SUPERETTE, a fluorescent-lighted relic amid the slick shops of Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is a mystery to many. Its timeworn counter is often unattended, and half-empty shelves display dusty canned foods. Neighborhood transplants cannot help wondering who is Joe? How does he stay in business? And why doesn't he replace the
title: TEMPTATION; Deep-Fried and Bite-Size

body: To the Editor: I recently moved to Seattle from New York, I love reading things that take me back, and I remember Sonny Payne. When I lived in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, I took the F train every day, and as soon as I saw the headline of your article, I remembered his line: ''If you don't have it, I can understand, because I don't have it.'' Paul
title: Sonny's Song

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger
body: The spring harvest of asparagus has just begun to show up in the city's Greenmarkets, and as a result on the menus of many restaurants. title: GOOD EATING; A Taste of Asparagus

body: By noon throughout the city, the faithful find their way to faded green storefronts. They are mostly men, and they have some thing things in common: time on their hands, money in their pockets, and the willingness to spend both trying to pick a winning horse. There are 78 Off-Track Betting outlets in New York City. And most of them -- they began
title: Win or Lose, a Place to Show; For Regulars, Betting Sites Double as Social Clubs

body: On Columbia Street along the Brooklyn waterfront stands a single sign announcing Irving Street. It is a standard green-and-white banner of the sort marking thousands of intersections in the city, and, like the one a few yards down for Sedgwick Street, there is nothing particularly remarkable about it. Except that, conventionally speaking, these
title: When the Street Name Outlives the Street; Only Signs Remain to Tell the Story Of New York's Ever-Changing Grid

title: The Nation: Moving Up or Out; It's Very Fancy on Old Delancey Street, You Know

title: Suburban Retailing for the New Brooklyn

author: Jim Dwyer, a reporter for The Times, is author of ''Subway Lives: 24 Hours in the Life of the New York City Subway'' (Crown).
body: ON fare-beating, the criminal cause and commercial activity around which his life found meaning, Alan Campbell speaks softly, almost monkishly. Far more than a simple acrobat who jumped turnstiles, or a bottom-feeding hustler who sucked tokens out of slots, Mr. Campbell worked on a scale of dizzying, historic proportion. He manufactured slugs by
title: 1904-2004; Fare-Beater Inc.

Bloomberg's overhaul of the schools had created a particularly difficult transition for children with special
title: New Deputy Says Fixing Special Education Is Paramount

body: IN the cosmology of New York City restaurants, there is no dessert more universal than the cheesecake. There are cheesecake variations playing in Manhattan dining rooms both upscale and down: at Gramercy Tavern, at Big Nick's, at ChikaLicious, at David Burke & Donatella. There is a strawberry-covered cheesecake on a pedestal at the Greek coffee
title: In Cheesecake City, a Quest for the Best

body: For some, South Brooklyn will always be South Brooklyn, although it is, in fact, in northern Brooklyn, and is also referred to, alternatively, as Carroll Gardens, Red Hook, Boerum Hill and the Columbia Waterfront District. But another name for the area has emerged, in the form of a well-appointed Web site and a series of sleek brochures: BoCoCa.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; The Newest Entry In Neighborhood Scrabble

body: It seems that you can't please anyone in New York City. People complained for years about having to recycle their trash. Then they complained when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg canceled most recycling to save the city money. And they positively howled in confusion when he restored some recycling but cut collections to every other week. So it should
title: Sorting Refuse Would Be a Snap If Only They Could Sort the Rules

body: ANY neighborhood would love to have a restaurant that feels as warm and inviting as Chestnut, but Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is the lucky winner. As you step inside, a little bar, practically glowing like a crackling fire, welcomes you like an old friend. I waited there one evening for friends. A glass of pilsner was expertly poured, and as I
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Crackling Glow of Welcome in Carroll Gardens

title: Bliss and Bigotry

body: To the Editor: I disagree with the characterization of the bishop crook street-lamp as ''inevitable." title: In Praise Of Boomburbs; And About Those Streetlamps

body: Brooklyn nurses its grudge against Manhattan with all the subtlety of King Kong, a Red Sox fan or Gerald R. Ford. title: Plugging a Hole in Brooklyn's Heart; A Web of Urban Challenges to Rival Dallas or Los Angeles
